name="navypedia">{{cite web |url= http://www.navypedia.org/ships/france/fr_ss_minerve.htm |title=Minerve submarines (1936-1939) |first=Ivan |last=Gogin |work=navypedia.org |year=2013 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> |Ship class= {{sclass-|Minerve|submarine}} |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement=*{{Convert|662|LT|t|0|lk=on}} surfaced *{{Convert|856|LT|t|0}} submerged |Ship length={{Convert|68.1|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{Convert|5.6|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught={{Convert|4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=*2 × [[Vickers-Armstrongs|Vickers]]-Normand diesel engines, {{Convert|1800|bhp|0|abbr=on}} *2 × Electric motors, {{Convert|1230|shp|0|abbr=on}} |Ship speed=*{{Convert|14.2|kn|lk=in}} surfaced *{{Convert|9|kn}} submerged |Ship range=*{{Convert|2000|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{Convert|10|kn}} surfaced *{{Convert|85|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{Convert|5|kn}} submerged |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth={{Convert|80|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=42 |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=* 1 × {{Convert|75|mm|in|0|abbr=on}}/35 Model 1928 [[deck gun]] with 150 rounds * 2 × {{Convert|13.2|mm|0|abbr=on}} AA machine guns * 6 × {{Convert|550|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} internal [[torpedo tube]]s (4 bow/2 stern) with 12 torpedoes * 3 × {{Convert|400|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} external torpedo tubes
|Ship armour= |Ship notes= }} |} '''''Iris'' (Q188)''' was a {{sclass-|Minerve|submarine}} of the [[French Navy]], commissioned in 1936. She was interned in Spain from November 1942, following the [[scuttling of the French fleet in Toulon]], finally returning to service post-war until 1950.
==Service history== The submarine was laid down on 1 July 1932 at the ''Ateliers et Chantiers Dubigeon'' shipyard at [[Nantes]], launched on 23 September 1934, and commissioned on 15 September 1936.<ref name="uboat.net">{{cite web |url= http://uboat.net/allies/warships/ship/6144.html |title=Iris |last=Helgason |first=Guðmundur |website=German U-boats of WWII - uboat.net |year=2013 |accessdate=8 March 2013 }}</ref>
On 27 November 1942, following the [[Case Anton|German occupation of Vichy]], the fleet at Toulon were ordered to scuttle their ships, however ''Iris'' was one of five submarines (the others were {{Ship|French submarine|Casabianca|Q183|2}}, {{Ship|French submarine|Marsouin|Q119|2}}, {{Ship|French submarine|Glorieux|Q168|2}}, and {{Ship|French submarine|Vénus|Q187|2}}) that disobeyed and attempted to escape, sailing from the harbour avoiding minefields and circling German [[Junkers Ju 88|Ju 88]] bombers. ''Iris'', under the command of ''[[Ship-of-the-line lieutenant|Lieutenant de vaisseau]]'' Degé, with a [[skeleton crew]] of only 17 men,<ref name="pagesperso">{{cite web | url=http://sous-marin.france.pagesperso-orange.fr/Q188.htm | title=Q188 Iris | work=sous-marin.france.pagesperso-orange.fr | accessdate=8 March 2013 | year=2008}}</ref> escaped from Toulon harbour and once in the open sea submerged until nightfall, evading the screen of German [[U-boat]]s stationed there to intercept them, and further out British submarines on the same mission.<ref name="sabordage">{{cite web |url= http://www.netmarine.net/forces/operatio/sabordage/recit.htm |title=Un récit du sabordage de la Flotte |first=Robert |last=Lagane |work=netmarine.net |year=2013|accessdate=8 March 2013|language=fr}}</ref>
''Iris'' sailed to [[Neutrality (international relations)|neutral]] Spain, arriving at [[Barcelona]] on the 28th. Under the terms of the [[Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907|1907 Hague Convention]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/hague13.asp |title=Rights and Duties of Neutral Powers in Naval War (Hague XIII); October 18, 1907 |work=avalon.law.yale.edu |year=2013 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> a warship can stay in a neutral port for a maximum of 48 hours or be interned. Degé contacted the French Consul General, who was unable to assist them in procuring any more food and fuel (of which they were desperately short) or gaining any extension to the deadline. After contacting the French Naval Attaché at Madrid the crew of ''Iris'' was offered a simple choice; internment or scuttling. They voted for internment. The crew were held at the prison camp at [[Miranda de Ebro]], while a Spanish crew under the supervision of Degé and ''[[Ensign (rank)|Enseigne de vaisseau]]'' Robert Lagane maintained the submarine.<ref name="sabordage"/>
In January 1943, in order to prevent any escape attempts, the propellers were removed, and in late February ''Iris'' was towed to [[Cartagena, Spain|Cartagena]].<ref name="pagesperso"/>
Finally, on 29 November 1945, ''Iris'' returned to France, and remained in service until decommissioned on 1 February 1950.<ref name="alamer"/>
